1070005248645783552.text: Every month or so I’ll print it all out, and think about structural stuff. The outline is part of the contract, so I don’t spend a lot of time playing with that once I’m writing: I write the best book I can within the confines of that structure.

1070005247781687296.text: I apply this to my books. When I write, I have a detailed outline. I plot out what section I’m going to work on each day. (1K words is a great day.) I use @ScrivenerApp because it’s very easy to assemble small pieces into chapters, and cross-device movement is great.

1070005246657609728.text: This is similar to the discipline behind deliberate practice: identifying and working on specific points of improvement, rather than just practicing scales or footwork or whatever. 1067964738221404160.text: It's well worth reading, especially if you're a parent. It'll help convince you that the kid you hope to get into Stanford or MIT should, in fact, be allowed to play sports and start a rock band, and shouldn't just do after-school tutoring and Kahn Academy until 1 AM.

1067964737122496512.text: (The article screen grabs, btw, are from Robert S. Root‐Bernstein, Maurine Bernstein & Helen Garnier, "Identification of scientists making long‐term, high‐impact contributions, with notes on their methods of working,” Creativity Research Journal 6:4 (1993), 329-343.)

1067963795710988288.text: So what's this all mean? Balancing long intensive hours with periods of "deep play" and hobbies; being athletic; and seeing yourself as *not* "ugh so busy!"-- that's how you change the world. The god of overwork is a false idol. Don't worship it. Live your life.

1067963791726436354.text: Finally, of course, there's my book on the way super-creative people integrate intense but short periods of work with deliberate rest, and why helped them be more creative and have longer creative lives: https://www.amazon.com/Rest-More-Done-When-Work/dp/1541617169/ref=as_li_ss_tl?_encoding=UTF8&qid=&sr=&linkCode=sl1&tag=contempcomput-20&linkId=861c4118dd1fece0319c07e163ec568f …pic.twitter.com/qNYCXY7QCg

1067963787003588608.text: Second, the high performers had a different attitude to time. They didn't worry so much about it, and often saw themselves as lazy. The low-performing group, in contrast, saw themselves as constantly time-stressed, and thought the solution was... to work longer hours.pic.twitter.com/U00ppwH2Mm

1067963782930911233.text: It wasn't performance on IQ tests. Rather, two other things really jumped out. The first was that the high performers had serious hobbies, or were lifelong athletes. (@NobelPrize laureate Donald Cram took up surfing in his 40s!) The low performers tended to not be athletes.pic.twitter.com/OsJSvBYR2M

1067960381157531650.text: Over the decades, they split into two groups: one group of high achievers (including 3 more @NobelPrize winners), science advisors, @theNASciences members, etc.; and a second group that struggled, that had low citation counts, etc. What separated the two groups?

1067960377101639680.text: In the 50s the group consisted of many promising young scientists from top schools just starting their careers (plus Linus Pauling, who had already won a Nobel prize). They were all smart, driven, ambitious. For all, the Future Looked Bright.pic.twitter.com/gfLlUwg8D0

1067960376023691265.text: Second thread: UCLA psychologists Bernice Eiduson and Maurine Bernstein conducted a longitudinal study of SoCal scientists from the 1950s to the 1980s. They interviewed them about their lives, work, recreation, problem-solving styles, etc. (For more see http://www.deliberate.rest/?p=810 )

1067957090080026624.text: Yesteryear's captains of industry worked hard when they needed to, but they appreciated the value of delegation, of building legacy organizations that could function without them, and of healthy recreation. (Of course, they also did bad stuff.)

1067956320408498177.text: tl:dr the ones who changed the world-- the Andrew Carnegie, John D Rockefeller, Henry Ford-level performers-- had serious hobbies that restored their nerves, helped determine how productive they could be on the job, and offered a vigorous critique of effete European elites.pic.twitter.com/aMv1TMhATt

1067955245500649472.text: First, Bertie Forbes (founder of @Forbes magazine) wrote a series of profiles of captains of industry that described their working lives, accomplishments, life philosophy, philanthropy-- and their hobbies and leisure activities. 1029012420751028224.text: The result? It took me 13 years to write and revise my first book. In the last 6 years, writing in the mornings, I’ve published 2 books and am deep into the third. So even if you think you work well, it’s worth experimenting with how you work. You may surprise yourself.

1029011165949583361.text: I’m NOT a natural morning person, but I’m more creative in the wee hours, I work without distractions (or self-distractions!), and there’s a quality to focus in those hours that’s unique (as any monk can tell you).

1029010449059143683.text: In my case, I had a Romantic idea that this was how creative people worked, and for a long time working from 9 or 10 PM to 2 or 3 AM worked well enough. But with a job and family, it wasn’t sustainable. So I tried flipping the day, and getting up at 5 AM to write.

1029009389988937729.text: As someone who only discovered the virtues of writing in the pre-dawn hours after 45 years of thinking I did my best writing late at night, I can say: it’s worth testing even your most basic assumptions about how you work best. You might be surprised.https://twitter.com/eveewing/status/1028809219942830080 …

1027381088513970176.text: It tells us that the familiar jocks-vs-nerds divide is just a matter of culture and adolescent tribalism. You can be both a great mind and a great athlete; and indeed, there are times when the two have been seen as completely complementary. [END]

1027380501361831936.text: And the same students started calling the people they hired to manage the rowing clubs, rugby clubs, etc., “coaches” too. So the term actually has its origins in the sciences, and then moves to sports. So why is this cool?

1027380130832773120.text: Back to the math and physics tutors. The best of them were famous for leading students through a course of study, the way a coachman led a team of horses along a difficult road. Eventually, the idea of tutors-as-coachman gave rise to the shorthand term... “coach.”

1027379615365382144.text: As a result, some of the 19th century’s most noted physicists, astronomers and mathematicians were also the university’s best athletes. Some sports (esp rowing) were thought to develop qualities very useful in the exams— perseverance, stamina, etc..

1027379265002590209.text: The exams lasted several days, and were notoriously difficult both mentally and physically. Some students collapsed with exhaustion during the exams; other had nervous breakdowns. So you needed to be in excellent physical shape to handle the stress and rigors of the exams.

1027378906607706113.text: There, students preparing for the notoriously rigorous final exams would do two things to prepare: they’d hire private tutors to help with their math and physics, and they played sports. The tutoring is pretty self-evident; but the sports was important, too.

1027378141432492034.text: Calling someone who manages a team and prepares athletes for competition “coach” is ubiquitous today, and the name appears to have originated in the 19th century— specifically, at Cambridge University. 2/x

1027377752003960832.text: “We Use Sports Terms All the Time. But Where Do They Come From?” https://nyti.ms/2KClMVM?smid=nytcore-ios-share … talks about “hat in the ring,” “hands down,” and other terms. I’ll add one that didn’t make it into the article: “coach.” 1/x

1015105306546728960.text: It’s not easy to do— we get all kinds of signals that tell us that overwork is everything from virtuous and romantic, to grimly necessary— but learning to rest “strategically and profoundly” is essential to doing the work you really want to do. /end

1015104574678429699.text: Steady periods of intensive focused work + periods of deliberate rest each day will get you farther, and yield better, more creative work. They also let you have a nicer life than if you alternate desperate grasping for superhuman productivity with periods of exhausted recovery.

1015104125736849409.text: We naturally spend more time working than is healthy, and will tend to work past the time we’re still effective. Add competition for grants / promotion / job market etc., and the result is a toxic belief in the utility and inevitability of overwork.
